title: State heal in progress
body:
Hi, I'm experiencing the same problem now. I had an unclean shutdown three days ago, node was offline for two hours, and it seems that it has not yet recovered. 

* Still `State heal in progress`
* Lots of `Unexpected trienode heal packet`
* `pending` seems to go up every time

I have been running geth on this machine for more than a year. SSD stats:

```
   READ: bw=112MiB/s (118MB/s), 112MiB/s-112MiB/s (118MB/s-118MB/s), io=3070MiB (3219MB), run=27321-27321msec
  WRITE: bw=37.6MiB/s (39.4MB/s), 37.6MiB/s-37.6MiB/s (39.4MB/s-39.4MB/s), io=1026MiB (1076MB), run=27321-27321msec
```

geth version `1.10.19-stable`

Is there something I should do to speed it up? Maybe increase bandwidth size? 

I'm running geth with default values for everything:

`geth --mainnet --datadir ... --http --http.api eth,net,web3`

_Originally posted by @newearthmartin in https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/issues/23191#issuecomment-1193129422_

Hi, I upgraded to `1.10.20-stable` and the problem still remains:

How long did the "state sync" phase take? State heal needs to fix up new trie nodes that were added/removed during the state sync phase, which if it takes long, will result in a large churn. This phase is a bit sensitive to network latency; do you have good connectivity and a decent latency?

Hi thanks for answering! 
what do you mean state sync phase? AFAIK the state heal is still going on.

I have a 100 mbps connection but it's largely unused even with geth beacon and validator. I m not sure about latency but it should be decent.

Maybe if I tell geth to use more bandwidth, this will be resolved?

FYI. I had the same issue. I waited a few hours. Then now it works well. 
In my case, I was watching geth logs.. suddenly I got lots of blocks in a few seconds.. then worked.  :(
Mine is in this state for several days now

Hi @karalabe and others 

I have some questions:

- in correct network/latency conditions, `pending` in `State heal in progress` should be going straight down? mine is erratic going up and down. When I reset the process the number goes back to 1 and starts growing.

- What is the relation between `State heal in progress` and `Unexpected trienode heal packet`? Why would I be seeing so many `Unexpected trienode heal packet`?

Every single time I have seen this issue, it had to do with IOPS or lack thereof. What make/model of storage is this?

Things I have seen that can cause issues:
- Heat ... smartctl -x. If that's above 50C, bring it down.
- RAID controllers that stop TRIM ... do HBA
- Too-slow cloud storage
- Some ultra-budget SSDs

Hi @yorickdowne thanks for answering

It's a [2TB WD Blue](https://www.amazon.com/Blue-NAND-2TB-SSD-WDS200T2B0B/dp/B073SBW3VD). I've been running geth, beacon, and validator on this system for more than a year, no problem.

Temperature is 34C

I don't know what RAID that stop TRIM is...  Here is the full smartctl -x output

@yorickdowne what command do you use to measure IOPS and what should be an acceptable result?

In my testing the WD Blue 3D NAND SATA is indeed fast enough. Your OS should auto-trim it. You can try a manual trim, from memory `sudo fstrim -a`.

I had [an issue](https://gist.github.com/yorickdowne/fd36009c19fdbee0337bffc0d5ad8284) with a system where a hardware RAID controller would not allow TRIM of the WD Blue SATA. That's not your setup here since you're in M.2 SATA. In my case, after about a year, the WD could no longer sync Geth and wouldn't successfully heal state. After trimming it, it was fine again.

macOS also stops TRIM to "non-Apple" SSDs by default. I am assuming you are on Linux, though.

Measuring IOPS will always be an approximation. I run 4G and 150G size tests as outlined here: https://eth-docker.net/docs/Usage/ResourceUsage#test-systems

Hi, yes, I'm running Ubuntu 22.04 and the `fstrim.timer` service is active.

Here are the 4G test results:

```
   READ: bw=102MiB/s (107MB/s), 102MiB/s-102MiB/s (107MB/s-107MB/s), io=3070MiB (3219MB), run=29989-29989msec

```
